metadata.name: Orbit of Influence #169
metadata.description:
Orbit of Influence is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, ZeroSpace NYC, 2023 and is a unique generative program created using processing's p5js and SVG. Developed from scratch, it employs a system of rule-based environments that have been a source of satisfaction for me since 1995.

The program generates three invisible planets, each at a different scale - small, medium, and large. Fifty objects then randomly select a planet, a speed to orbit around it, and one of three brush sizes - small, medium, or large. These objects move around their respective planets, painting color and texture across the planetary orbit in three-dimensional space.

To reveal the blueprint of the system, press the "s" key on your keyboard. The hidden algorithm that governs the brushes' movement is then displayed, revealing a mesmerizing display of synchronized choreography as the brushes interconnect with each other.

Press the following keys to interact :

- '1': swap the background color to "ocean"
- '2': swap the background color to "mist"
- '3': swap the background color to "lilac"
- '4': swap the background color to "amethyst"
- '5': swap the background color to "crimson"
- '6': swap the background color to "emerald"

- 'l': toggle animation loop on/off
- 's': system reveal, show the blueprint of the algorithm

Joshua Davis / PrayStation 'Orbit of Influence' / (2023) real-time generative program, 1240 x 1653 px, Date Minted: April 2023

Twitter: @joshuadavis
Instagram: @praystation
Website: https://joshuadavis.com

Bio :

Since 1995, Joshua Davis is an artist, technologist, author and designer in algorithmic image making & animation. Using programming, he writes his own code to produce interactions with users and to generate visual compositions according to rule-based, randomized processes.

Joshua has exhibited his works and/or lectured at the Ars Electronica (Austria), Centre Georges Pompidou (France), Contemporary Arts Center (Cincinnati), J. Paul Getty Museum (Los Angeles),  the Tate Modern (London), the Design Museum (London), the Institute of Contemporary Arts (London), PS.1 MoMA (New York), the Whitney (New York), the Smithsonian‚Äôs Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum (New York), the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (Spain), among others.

Since 2000, Joshua has lectured globally about his work, inspirations and motivations at museums, galleries, institutions, art festivals, etc., and has spoken at the TED (2005) and 99U (2013) conferences about his career in algorithmic image making and open source.

metadata.name: Dialect: Bold #69
metadata.description:
Dialect: Bold is the wild younger sibling of Dialect. As both Dialect collections are created using a string of text as the main input, "Bold" is also a play on the term used to denote the weight of a font. Many aesthetic decisions were made along the way to completing Dialect. Dialect: Bold is what would have happened had a different path been taken. Complimentary but different. Bold!

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save a high-resolution version of the image

Made in p5js
Created March 2023
By John Ryan

metadata.name: Block Storage #15
metadata.description:
VGAB::BLOCKS2/STORAGE

Generative Storage Blocks made with P5JS and random colors.

Save image as PNG with 's'.
Save image as JPG with 'S'.

Load 1x, 2x or 4x dimensions (2560 * 3840px) image with '1', '2' or '4'.

Remove / add white noise with 'n'.
Remove / add frames with 'f'.

** 4x pixelDensity tested only with Google Chrome **
** Blocks Series reserves always from the Block Office **


VGAB 2023 / CC BY-NC 4.0

metadata.name: A24Z #344
metadata.description:
Every artist and collector feels the joy of both creating and collecting. But if I could share the joy of creating with collectors. And collectors with their family and friends, what may be an additive process of joy is now perhaps exponential. Joy to the power of 26 to be exact. 

In this work I invite my friends and collectors to collaborate with me. Though not in coding, but together in a process of creating narratives and visuals. Code and story. We didn‚Äôt use github, just a simple p5.js editor to try out different programs and palettes. Pedrofe and J0rdan pick their palettes tastefully and carefully. okeoke, perhaps more of a genius than he lets on, picks his palettes blind. No hex color picker. Just straight up rhymes.  

In our discussions verbal language was forbidden. Only emojis were allowed to express our tastes and views. Each emojis put down on google doc was taken with absolutely seriousness. 

Pedro: Loves to taking his daily walks on ‚ÄúMagic Mushroom Mountain‚Äù

J0rdan: Wonders about ‚ÄúQuark Question Quiches‚Äù

Okeoke: Just get lost in ‚ÄúFinnegans‚Äô Flower Fields.‚Äù

It has been a great joy to present our illustration book A24Z, 8 more than you know who. Each page expresses the alphabet with the best of our knowledge in semantics and sarcasm. Collect just 1 page, collect the alphabets that spell out your name, collect the whole A to Z. Read it to your children or loved ones. Though you might need to interpolate or extrapolate with great imagination which children all have. But most importantly, like all children, have fun!

Press 1 to save png, only for Chrome, not Safari. Preview images are compressed or broken, test capture at 300 sec.

License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Isola della Scala #15
metadata.description:
All things pass, all things flow,
Movement, connection, separation, all in tow.
A misstep and we're knocked off course,
But in the end, we rise, as if by force.
Like a dance of dominoes, we fall and we stand,
In this ever-changing world, we're a part of the grand.

The name of this work is the name of the city where my roots began, where the path of everything changed and new directions in life were taken.

Made with p5.js, p5.grain and much love

metadata.name: Root #17
metadata.description:
Root, by Matthew Plummer-Fernandez (2022). A pseudo-simulation of plant intelligence and root systems. Each root apex splinters into more apexes that follow similar trajectories in swarm-like patterns. To illustrate a basic response to their surroundings, each root system is confined to an invisible container that the root tips appear to either inspect or repel from, framing the final state. The system is sensitive to the space containing it, so it may grow in another way on different screen sizes. 

Inspired by The Revolutionary Genius of Plants: A New Understanding of Plant Intelligence and Behavior, by scientist and author Stefano Mancuso.

Press 's' key in live mode to save a png.

The code that generates this work also contains an essay titled 'Root: hashing out the concept of regenerative art'

Press the '/' key (a symbol used for the 'root' directory) in live mode to save the essay as a txt file (best viewed copy/pasted into a word processor).

Vers

metadata.name: Annum #7558
metadata.description:
This project is being released in celebration of the 1 year aniversary of Achromat, my first release on fxhash. In addition to being inspired by Achromat, aspects of other previous projects have been incorporated. My deepest gratitude to all who have collected my work over the past year.

In live mode, add &size=<YOUR_PIXEL_SIZE> to change the pixel size of the image for export (Right click to save). For example, &size=4000 will set the width of the image to be 4000 pixels.

50% of primary sales go to Savepakistan.

metadata.name: haluna #128
metadata.description:

Textural pattern studies with XOR operator.

Best experienced in fullscreen.

- 7 different fixed color palettes & an algorithmic color palette generator.

- 2 different canvas aspect ratio.

In live mode, press ‚Äòs‚Äô to save as PNG (1500 x 2000px or 2666 x 2000px )

Made with p5.js

Ilgƒ±n ƒ∞√ß√∂z√º, June 2022
@distcollective

metadata.name: A Bugged Forest #80
metadata.description:
A forest has stories to tell.
About times that were, about times that will be.
-
This project was minted in much unusual conditions. 
We gathered here, by 38 degrees heat. We belong to a crowd who loves stories, of civilisations at stake and deities, of afterlife and worship. We drank and hugged and chanted pagan hymns. We minted the Bugged Forest from our place on earth that we call Hell just for the fun of it. We are passionate, and loving, and angry and desperate. We, people of the soil, under a bugged sun.
-
This project is the long-form version of an algorithm that contains a bug. ‚ÄúThe Bugged Tree‚Äù‚Äôs code was salvaged and stored and served as the core motivation and engine for an entire forest. Its concept is about releasing the control. I am a  byproduct of evolution, an iteration of that specie who wanted utter control, and which at some point, lost control over its own creation. As a generative artist, I chose to welcome the event of chance into my creative process. The symbolism in chance made me feel humble and free. Unwilling to make any change to a story that the Tree needed to tell me, as a listener, rather than a writer of my own idealised fantasies.
-
The iterations aren‚Äôt under control. They may be odd and off. We have to accept it. They are also plottable, press [s] in live mode to get a SVG. Attempt the plot at your own risk, as there‚Äôs a possibility for it to come near to impossibilities or cause paper or motor damage, and most certainly, a bugged drawing.
-
From Earth or from Hell, with love, yours truthfully, NFTBiker and zancan

metadata.name: Action; System #8
metadata.description:
Action; system is an experimental study inspired by the work of Fran√ßois Morellet. Morellet was one of the founders of the Groupe de Recherche d'Art Visuel (GRAV), founded in the 60s. His work was often informed by systems, a set of rules that determine the artwork, reducing the artist's subjectivity to a minimum.

This work explores what happens when we let go of the strict rule set. Do we ever fully let go?

-----------------
This work was released for the 2023 fundraising exhibition Cure3, and all of the proceeds and 1% of royalties will go to Parkinson's research funds. You can find more information at https://cure3.co.uk/.

-----------------
Controls
- R: new randomized output (the chances of recovering one of these outputs are very slim, that's what the next control is for)
- E: high-res output
- Double click: fullscreen

While you see the eye of Horus, your artwork is loading.

------------------
Made with p5.js & glsl
License: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

metadata.name: Teardrop #7
metadata.description:
I started this work as an introspection to my comprehension on the book of Wumen Guan (ÁÑ°ÈñÄÈóú), the gateless barrier. 

A question posed by zen master, Wumen Huikai (ÁÑ°ÈñÄÊÖßÈñã), to whether there was a gate, at a given barrier, where one would wish to pass? There were, of course, infinite many ways to compose such a paradox. 

As I explored through different forms and composition, the gates had become either hearts and/or eyes looking upon us. The barrier (Èóú guan), a type of blockade of something, effectively became a perspective, (ËßÄ guan), the watching over of some things with love.  

I realized, it was then trivial to debate whether and how such gates exist. And whether something in the sky was flying in and out of gates or non gates, is no more significant than if they were only the teardrops of someone, watching over us, cheering us on. The answer was a simple question of love. 

Press 1 to save png. Chrome only. Preview images are compressed.
